docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: When Ronald Wilkinson, an air-traffic controller at Dulles Airport in Washington, tested positive for the AIDS virus last year, he began taking AZT, a drug that helps delay the onset of AIDS in people, like Mr. Wilkinson, who are infected with the virus but do not show symptoms of the disease.

headline.main: Air Controller Fights Removal Over AIDS Drug

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said yesterday that they were ending an agreement to transfer Rorer's Maalox antacid franchise in the United States to Procter & Gamble.
docs.snippet: LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said yesterday that they were ending an agreement to transfer Rorer's Maalox antacid franchise in the United States to Procter & Gamble.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Esther and Leonard Farb, an elderly couple in Upper Manhattan, often feel like prisoners in their own home. Fear of crime keeps them inside at night, and they often stay inside during the day, too, because the elevators are chronically broken, they say, and they are too weak to take the stairs.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In the strongest language it has used so far, the top Federal advisory panel on AIDS issued a three-part report today assailing the Government's drug testing programs, the nation's rural health care system and the ''shocking number'' of medical professionals it said were unwilling to treat people infected with the virus.

headline.main: Panel Issues Broad Attack On U.S. Response to AIDS
